intro: Quercus pseudomolucca var. angustata, commonly known as the narrow-leaf mangrove oak, is a variant of the broad-leaf mangrove oak native to Southeast Asia. It is a deciduous tree characterized by its narrow, elongated leaves that are typically 5–10 cm in length. The plant produces small, acorn-like fruits that are an important food source for various wildlife species. It thrives in coastal and brackish water environments, often found in mangrove forests. Its botanical features make it well adapted to saline and tidal conditions, contributing to its ecological significance in coastal ecosystems.
